intro: Leptanthus virginicus, commonly known as the Virginia leptanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers that range in color from white to pink. It typically grows in wet, wooded areas and thrives in partial to full shade. Leptanthus virginicus is often found in swampy or marshy habitats, where it plays a role in the local ecosystem.
